medium: Charcoal and gray wash on gray laid paper, pieced
creditline: Gift of Frank Jewett Mather Jr.

makers.displaydate: 1483–1520; born Rome, Italy; died Urbino, Italy
makers.displaymaker: School of Raphael, 1483–1520; born Rome, Italy; died Urbino, Italy

texts.textentryhtml: Easily erased, charcoal was often employed in the making of a cartoon, or cartone, a large piece of paper used to transfer the final design for a painting or fresco to its support. The absence of pricked holes or incisions along the outlines of the contours indicates that this cartoon was not used.

bibliography.boilertext: Exhibition of drawings by old masters from the private collection of Prof. Frank Jewett Mather: International Art Center of Roerich Museum: December 18th to 31st, 1930, (New York: Roerich Museum, 1930).
